Timeline of Columbia and Barnard affirmative action key precedents

1928: Zora Neale Hurston is the first Black student to graduate from Barnard

1954: Brown v. Board of Education

This landmark U.S. Supreme Court case declared racial segregation in public schools unconstitutional. It sparked national movements for racial integration in higher education, pressuring elite institutions like Columbia and Barnard to diversify.

1960s to 1970s: Affirmative Action Gains Ground

Columbia and Barnard begin actively recruiting students of color, particularly after the civil rights movement and nationwide student activism.

1968: Columbia protests, led by Black students, push for increased representation and resources for marginalized students.

1995

2002

2003: Bollinger and the Supreme Court

Former Columbia President Lee Bollinger, then president of the University of Michigan, defends race-conscious admissions before the U.S. Supreme Court in two cases: Grutter v. Bollinger and Gratz v. Bollinger. The court upholds affirmative action in Grutter, affirming the educational benefits of diversity. Bollinger becomes a key national figure in the legal defense of affirmative action.

1975

2023: Affirmative Action Overturned

In Students for Fair Admissions v.

Harvard University and University of

North Carolina, the Supreme Court

rules race-conscious admissions

unconstitutional, ending the

decades-long precedent on

affirmative action. Columbia and

Barnard issue statements reaffirming

commitment to diversity but adjust

their admission policies.

2012

2024: Columbia & Barnard’s First Class Post-Affirmative Action

Columbia and Barnard hold their first admission cycle without affirmative action.

2004

Source: Spectator Reporting

Graphic by Alison Chiu

Timeline of Columbia and Barnard affirmative action key precedents

1928: Zora Neale Hurston is the first Black student to graduate from Barnard

1954: Brown v. Board of Education

This landmark U.S. Supreme Court case declared racial segregation in public schools unconstitutional. It sparked national movements for racial integration in higher education, pressuring elite institutions like Columbia and Barnard to diversify.

1960s to 1970s: Affirmative Action Gains Ground

Columbia and Barnard begin actively recruiting students of color, particularly after the civil rights movement and nationwide student activism.

1968: Columbia protests, led by Black students, push for increased representation and resources for marginalized students.

1995

1975

2002

2003: Bollinger and the Supreme Court

Former Columbia President Lee Bollinger, then president of the University of Michigan, defends race-conscious admissions before the U.S. Supreme Court in two cases: Grutter v. Bollinger and Gratz v. Bollinger. The court upholds affirmative action in Grutter, affirming the educational benefits of diversity. Bollinger becomes a key national figure in the legal defense of affirmative action.

2004

2012

2023: Affirmative Action Overturned

In Students for Fair Admissions v. Harvard University and University of North Carolina, the Supreme Court rules race-conscious admissions unconstitutional, ending the decades-long precedent on affirmative action. Columbia and Barnard issue statements reaffirming commitment to diversity but adjust their admission policies.

2024: Columbia & Barnard’s First Class Post-Affirmative Action

Columbia and Barnard hold their first admission cycle without affirmative action.

Source: Spectator Reporting
